EXECUTIVE SUMMARY





This document comprises the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the Kemira Water Solutions, Inc. facility located at 18700 Highway 14 North in Mojave, California 93501 (also referred to as the Mojave Plant).  The facility is located in an undeveloped area approximately 1.5 miles northeast of the town of Mojave.  The Mojave Airport, which is the nearest neighboring facility, is approximately 1 mile away. 



The purpose of this document is to comply with various risk management planning requirements.  These are set forth in Section 25535(d) of Article 2 of Chapter 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code (also known as the California Accidental Release Prevention Program - CalARP) and Part 68 of Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40CFR Part 68).  The latter is also known as the federal Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs or the federal RMP.  



The scope of the RMP includes all operations conducted at Kemira Water Solutions, Inc. Mojave facility which involve the storage, handling and/or use of chlorine.   Chlorine is the only regulated substance which is handled at the facility above the threshold quantity.  





ES 1.0 DESCRIPTION OF STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



PRIMARY OPERATIONS



The primary operation conducted at Kemira Water Solutions, Inc. Mojave facility is the manufacture of ferrous chloride and ferric chloride solutions (NAICS Code 32518, SIC Code 2819).  The primary components utilized in the process include water, hydrochloric acid, chlorine, and scrap iron.  Chlorine is a regulated substance subject to the above-referenced regulations, and is the only such regulated substance handled at the facility.  Provided below is a brief description of the storage, handling, and use of chlorine at the site.

In developing these release scenarios, a number of hypothetical accidental release scenarios were postulated and evaluated for the RMP. Each of these categories of hypothetical accidental release scenarios is discussed in the technical studies maintained at the facility.





ES 3.0 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



During the five years preceding the submittal of this RMP, the facility has had one minor release of chlorine with no related injuries or impact.  The incident occurred on 9/17/2013.  Chlorine gas escaped as a result of a flange failure on a feed line to one of the process tanks.  The incident resulted in a release of <0.1 pounds of chlorine gas.  An employee was working nearby and smelled the chlorine.   The employee thought the leak was coming from a chlorine line valve flange.  The employee tested with ammonia solution and confirmed the leak.  The Plant Manager was notified and the plant was immediately shut down for repair of the flange.  The incident was investigated and corrective actions were completed; the case was closed by 12/16/13.  During this incident there were no:

- Onsite injuries;

- Onsite deaths or significant property damage; or

- Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.





ES 4.0 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The Accidental Release Prevention Program at Kemira Water Solutions, Inc. Mojave facility consists of a series of programs, procedures, and policies designed to minimize the risk of accidental releases involving chlorine.  These programs include design and operating controls, compliance with specified codes, the facility's health and safety program, numerous standard operat

ing procedures, the equipment inspection and maintenance program (including a mechanical integrity and preventive maintenance program), site security, the management of change program, pre-startup safety review, fire prevention/fire protection/hot work permit program, management and safety of contractors, accident/incident investigation procedures, emergency response plan, RMP compliance auditing program, record keeping, and a variety of training programs.  Details of each of these components of the facility's Accidental Release Prevention Program are provided in the document entitled Risk Management Plan (RMP), Volume I - Prevention Program (maintained at the facility).  



There are several chlorine leak detection and monitoring devices and other protective devices (e.g., for fire protection, etc.) placed at strategic locations throughout the facility.  In addition, the site has both manual and automatic shutoff systems to stop the flow of chlorine in an emergency.





ES 5.0 EMERGENCY RESPONSE



Kemira Water Solutions, Inc. recognizes that emergency planning and emergency response are an integral component of risk management.   As such, the Mojave Plant currently has emergency action plans and emergency evacuation plans in place.  In addition, the facility has developed a Fire Prevention Plan.  These programs work together to mitigate the effects of unplanned releases or events.  However, as a continuous measure to improve safety, the facility reviews its emergency response plan, evacuation plan, and fire prevention plan on a regular basis.  This review process also ensures that the facility incorporates the latest safety developments into its existing programs.





ES 6.0 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



A detailed hazard and operability study (i.e., hazards analysis) was performed on ALL operations involving chlorine in order to evaluate the potential for accidental releases on 29-30 November 2011.  As required under the California Code of Regulations,

Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, section 2745.7 (q)(1-4) and 40 CFR 68, the hazards analysis included an analysis of natural and human-caused external events.  As a result of the most recent audit, only minor changes to Standard Operating Procedures were identified that will be part of the ongoing continuous improvement at the site.   Additionally, in 1991 the facility conducted a detailed seismic risk assessment.  In addition, annual seismic walk-downs are conducted.
